document.heading: Resolution Number TMBC217-03-23 of the Duly Elected and Certified Governing Body of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians

citations.citation: Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians Res. No. 217-03-23

recital.text: the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians, hereinafter referred to as the Tribe, is an unincorporated Band acting under a revised Constitution and By-Laws approved by the Secretary of the Interior on June 16th, 1959 and amendments thereto approved; and

Article IX(a) Section 1 of the Turtle Mountain Constitution and By-Laws empowers the Tribal Council with the authority to represent the Band and to negotiate with Federal, State, and Local Governments and with private persons; and

Article IX(a) Section 1 of the Turtle Mountain Constitution and By-Laws requires a 30-day comment period prior to the adoption of any ordinances or amendments to the Tribal Code, whether proposed by resolution or otherwise. Adoption must occur through a roll call vote of the Tribal Council at a publicly held meeting; and
the Tribe is proposing revisions to Title 1, Criminal Procedure Code to provide for changes to complaints to add additional specificity; and
the Tribe, by Resolution No. TMBC107-02-23, approved a 30 day public comment period for proposed revisions to Title 1, Criminal Procedure Code, and no comments were made; now
that the Tribe is approving revisions to the Tribal code, Title 1, Criminal Procedure Code, as published in the comment period notice; and
that the Tribal Code will be codified accordingly, to insert amendments to the Tribal Code, Title 1.

procedural-data.text: I, the undersigned Tribal Secretary of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians, do hereby certify that the Tribal Council is composed of nine (9) members of whom seven (7) constituting a quorum were present at a meeting duly called, convened and held on the 23rd day of March, 2023 that the foregoing resolution was adopted by affirmative vote of six (6) in favor - Representatives Elmer Davis Jr., Blaine "Slugger" Davis, Craig Lunday, Kenneth Malaterre, Ron Trottier Sr. and Chad Counts; two (2) absent- Representatives Lynn Gourneau and Jon Jon Keplin; none (0) opposed; with the Chairman not voting.

section.heading: Contents of Complaint; a Complaint Must Contain

para.text: the name of the jurisdiction where it is filed;
the names of the person(s), government, or business(es), complained of, if the defendant(s) name is known, and if not, then such name(s) as may be given by the complainant;
a statement signed by the complainant attesting to the facts constituting the offense, in plain and concise language;
the time and place of the commission of the offense, as near as may be ascertained;
the general name and statute of the crime or public offense committed;
the person, government, or business against whom, or against whose property, the offense was committed, if known; and
if the offense is against the property of any person, government, or business, a general description of such property.

para.text: The completed complaint must be filed by the Prosecutor with the Clerk of Court who shall mark thereon the date and time of the filing.

A completed complaint filed by a Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) or a Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa Indians (TMBCI)Tribal Law Enforcement Officer with the Prosecutor must be accompanied by an initial report describing the incident and offense(s), unless it is a traffic offense not involving alcohol or drugs.
The Prosecutor has a duty to verify that each complaint and report meets the requirements of the Tribal Court, before filing it with the Clerk of Court.
